articles.headline: China Quick to Execute Drug Official
articles.snippet: The execution was meant to show that Beijing is serious about improving the safety of Chinese products.
articles.abstract: The execution was meant to show that Beijing is serious about improving the safety of Chinese products.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING, July 10 — China executed its former top food and drug regulator on Tuesday for taking bribes to approve untested medicine, as the Beijing leadership scrambled to show that it was serious about improving the safety of Chinese products.

articles.headline: McCain Campaign Drops Top Aides; New Doubts Rise
articles.snippet: The departure left Senator John McCain’s campaign team gutted and raised new doubts about his ability to continue in the race.
articles.abstract: The departure left Senator John McCain’s campaign team gutted and raised new doubts about his ability to continue in the race.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 10 — After months of mounting problems in his presidential campaign, Senator John McCain sat down with his two top political aides on Monday for what turned out to be a loud and acrimonious discussion in his Senate office.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Balmy Weather May Bench a Baseball Staple
articles.snippet: In towns like Russell, Pa., the future of the ash tree is in doubt because of a beetle and a warming climate.
articles.abstract: In towns like Russell, Pa., the future of the ash tree is in doubt because of a beetle and a warming climate.
articles.lead_paragraph: RUSSELL, Pa. — Careers at stake with each swing, baseball players leave little to sport when it comes to their bats. They weigh them. They count their grains. They talk to them.

articles.headline: Can’t Sell Your Home? Maybe It’s Priced Too Low
articles.snippet: Even as foreclosures rise and overall sales plummet, more expensive homes have staged a bit of a comeback.
articles.abstract: Even as foreclosures rise and overall sales plummet, more expensive homes have staged a bit of a comeback.
articles.lead_paragraph: Given that the real estate market is supposed to be in free fall, some strange things have been happening recently in Mill Valley.

articles.headline: Accuser Says Web Site for Teenagers Has X-Rated Link
articles.snippet: Stickam, a Web site that allows its users, ages 14 and older, to participate in unfiltered video chats, has close ties to an online pornography business, according to a former company vice president.
articles.abstract: Stickam, a Web site that allows its users, ages 14 and older, to participate in unfiltered video chats, has close ties to an online pornography business, according to a former company vice president.
articles.lead_paragraph: Parents and child safety experts concerned about the online activities of teenagers have been particularly nervous about a Web site called Stickam, which allows its 600,000 registered users, age 14 and older, to participate in unfiltered live video chats using their Web cameras.

articles.headline: Rate Agencies Move Toward Downgrading Some Mortgage Bonds
articles.snippet: The move was a tacit acknowledgment that credit rating firms might have been too optimistic about the housing market.
articles.abstract: The move was a tacit acknowledgment that credit rating firms might have been too optimistic about the housing market.
articles.lead_paragraph: The slumping housing market again rattled the bond market yesterday.

articles.headline: Mr. Kravis Goes to Washington (Capra Rolls Over)
articles.snippet: Private equity managers like Henry R. Kravis are fighting a fierce, uphill lobbying battle over one of the most contentious tax proposals in the last decade.
articles.abstract: Private equity managers like Henry R. Kravis are fighting a fierce, uphill lobbying battle over one of the most contentious tax proposals in the last decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 10 — Henry R. Kravis, the billionaire founder of the corporate buyout movement, was working the hallways of Capitol Hill, hoping to kill legislation that would raise his taxes and those of other investment fund executives.
articles.byline: By Stephen Labaton and Jenny Anderson
